item.title: Ticket #2639 (Previous Posts link not working with permalinks) created
item.dc:creator: bradbice

Previous Posts link looks like:

â€‹http://www.domain.com/index.phpIndex.php/page/2/

On IIS with php.ini set to:

cgi.fix_pathinfo = 1 cgi.force_redirect = 0

and permalinks set to:

Custom - /index.php/%postname%/

item.title: Ticket #2638 (Title output in wp_list_pages() may render $title_li with backslashes ...) created
item.dc:creator: lordjiem
item.description:
When trying the new Widgets plugin, I noticed that if I use the page list widget, its xhtml output is badly formed: 

<h2 class=\"widgettitle\">Pages</h2>

instead of 

<h2 class="widgettitle">Pages</h2>

and that in spite of the fact that the call to wp_list_pages() is made with well formated input in the function widget_pages().

So it seems that the $title_li is not cleaned before output in the wp_list_pages() function.

Currently it is : 

if ( $r['title_li'] )
	$output .= '<li class="pagenav">' . $r['title_li'] . '<ul>';

when it should be, from my point of view: 

if ( $r['title_li'] )
	$output .= '<li class="pagenav">' .  stripslashes($r['title_li']) . '<ul>';

to make it render correctly in xhtml.

item.title: Ticket #2637 (Update title and link fields in feeds) updated
item.dc:creator: stewart
item.description: Component changed

item.title: Ticket #2637 (Update title and link fields in feeds) created
item.dc:creator: stewart
item.description:
WP 2.x has made it super easy to get a feed of just about everything, which is great.

But the wp-rss2.php and wp-atom.php templates are still hardcoded as if there's just one main feed for a site, which is not so great because it confuses feed aggregators when you try to subscribe to multiple feeds from the same site.

Could we maybe try something along the lines of 

<channel>
	<title><?php bloginfo_rss('name'); wp_title() ?></title>
	<link><?php print("http://".$_SERVER['HTTP_HOST'].$_SERVER['REQUEST_URI']); ?></link>

in the next go-round?

item.title: thorn.diff attached to Ticket #2634
item.dc:creator: skeltoac

item.title: Ticket #2634 (wp_texturize kills some valid entities) created
item.dc:creator: skeltoac
item.description:
Current regex: /&([#])(?[a-z1-4]{1,8};)/

Entities not recognized by this: THORN ETH AElig OElig lArr rArr uArr dArr

This expression resolves it: /&([#])(?[a-zA-Z1-4]{1,8};)/

This bug was reported by an Icelandic blogger at â€‹http://andrisig.wordpress.com/

item.title: Ticket #2633 (It's sometimes hard to see any response from the list manipulation AJAX) updated
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description:
Keywords changed

2633.diff

  1. Displays a link to the newly added list item.
  2. Makes list-manipulation errors/status messages more inline with WP's other messages.
  3. Fixes HTML/CSS bug in cat listing on Add Bookmark page.
  4. Simplifies list-manipulation reseting of form data.
  5. Moves the location of the AJAX response element (where notices and errors are put) around in a few places. Particularly, that for categories.php is now to the right of the title and parent form elements. I'll let someone else figure out where these elements should be best placed here and in other places.

item.title: 2633.diff attached to Ticket #2633
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description: Display a link to the newly added list item.

item.title: Ticket #2633 (It's sometimes hard to see any response from the list manipulation AJAX) created
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description: When adding items to long lists, the new item can be added somewhere off the screen. The markup/CSS of the admin pages could be redesigned to prevent this where possible. A complementaly solution would be to dispaly a link to the anchor of the new element on successful addition.

item.title: Ticket #1038 (Limit access to php files) updated
item.dc:creator: szepter
item.description:
It'd be nice to block access to wp-config.php "just in case"; if something goes wrong with Apache and it stops parsing PHP files

It's improbable that something goes wrong with Apache and it stops parsing PHP files ... but if so, defines in the wp-config.php or wherever wouldn't solve that problem. These files will be available either way.

In case of the PHP config stops working - I think - also .htaccess-limitations wouldn't join.

The same applies to the plugin solution. This plugin wouldn't be executed if something goes wrong with Apache.

item.title: Ticket #2628 (wordpress broken under apache mod_fastcgi with php ran as a cgi) updated
item.dc:creator: scruby
item.description:
I need to add something to this:

â€‹http://bugs.php.net/bug.php?id=36705 rears its ugly head in several places. There's no reason in the world to send a header_status(200) in classes.php function handle_404. If you send nothing, php will assume you mean 200 by default. On the other hand, if you send status_header(200), then send header("Location: . . . ") you'll end up sending an extra Status: 302 header, and fastcgi will have an internal server error again. This breaks stuff like a click on the trackback link. So, in addition to the change mentioned above, you need to take out the status_header( 200 ); from classes.php

There's no point in doing status_header(200) anyway.

item.title: Ticket #2597 (304 Not Modified Headers not returned in RSS2 feed) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
All my testing indicates that $_SERVER is, in fact, quoted by magic_quotes_gpc

There are a limited number of HTTP headers you can inject quotes into just by using a browser, so I opened up a telnet session and injected quotes everywhere that I could (without invalidating the HOST, for example) and found that all these places were slashed when magic_quotes_gpc was on.

I'm running PHP 4.3.10-16

The PHP documentation on this is wrong, or at best, incomplete.

Was the alleged vulnerability with $_SERVER ever tested? I don't see a ticket associated with the commit. It could have just been submitted to security@â€¦
